Author: gruseom
Content:
We defer DOM manipulations to the end of each "run loop" where we coalesce them, removing redundant operations

That's very interesting. Can you give examples of redundant operations that you coalesce?

I'm wondering if this approach might help in my case. I'm frequently repositioning/resizing thousands of little divs. Any suggestions?

Author: reinspruch
Content: Wind down the company, i.e. Chapter 7. Then each of you can take what you have done and run with it. If he is not motivated now then he will be even less so post-bankruptcy. If you are motivated now then you will be even more so once you control 100% of the company.

Author: jmtulloss
Content: I couldn't agree more. I think the distinction is that inherently irreplaceable people are irreplaceable no matter where they are put. Some people are irreplaceable just because they're the only one that knows anything about X.

Author: kaens
Content:
I'm also fairly inexperienced, but it seems to me that as long as there is a clean separation between modules (which there should be anyway), that it would work rather well.

Do you do code reviews on each others modules?

Author: jwilliams
Content:
#3 - Seems to indicate that everyone in your team must be replaceable. This is good from a management and operational perspective.

...but you can't stop people who are just damn good. In fact, often this hampers them - i.e. You're too good at X, so you have to train a whole bunch of people who are bad at it otherwise it's a risk. This is often applied irrespective of the skill/talent of the person involved and the rest of the team respectively.

Sometimes people just are irreplaceable. What you don't want are people who are irreplaceable because of systemic issues.
